docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee posted the full version of its health care bill on the committee Web site on Monday. (A link is provided on the Prescriptions blog.) The legislation provides a blueprint for ''affordable, quality health care for all Americans'' and for ''other purposes.'' And at 1,502 pages, there are more than a few other purposes.
docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee posts on Internet full, 1,502-page version of its health care bill; Senate Democratic leaders are working to combine it with 839-page health measure that Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee approved in July (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The government health insurance program for people who are 65 and older, blind or permanently disabled. In 2008, the $460 billion program provided health coverage to about 45 million people.
docs.abstract: Definition of Medicare, which provides health coverage to about 45 million people in US (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Prescriptions column on Monday, by David M. Herszenhorn, analyzed the effort by some Congressional Democrats to adjust permanently a Medicare payment formula that for years has threatened to impose steep annual cuts in payments to doctors. The formula was originally devised to reduce Medicare's costs. The permanent adjustment is projected to cost Medicare $250 billion more over 10 years. But supporters of the solution say it should not count toward the cost of the broader effort to overhaul the health care system, which President Obama has promised would not add to the nation's deficits. Dozens of readers weighed in on the Prescriptions blog. Here are two of their comments:
docs.abstract: Sampling of reader responses to David Herszenhorn's October 19 Prescriptions column analyzing efforts by Congressional Democrats to adjust Medicare payment formula (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats and White House officials met on Monday evening to discuss how to merge the two versions of the Senate's health care legislation, and Democratic aides said they were aiming to have a combined bill ''mostly baked'' by the end of this week. Once the bills are melded, the Congressional Budget Office will be asked to develop a revised cost analysis, which will take several days. At that point, provided everything is in order, the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, will look to start the floor debate.
docs.abstract: Senate Democrats and White House officials meet to discuss how to merge two versions of Senate's health care legislation; five main points of contention discussed (M)
